content: The "Virginia Jobs and Energy Act" is also known as the Lease Sale 220 and Other OCS Oil and Gas Lease Sales Offshore Virginia. The "Virginia Jobs and Energy Act" mandates the Secretary of the Interior to conduct lease sale 220 within a year of enactment. Additionally, at least 2 lease sales in the Virginia lease sale planning area must be included in future 5-year oil and gas leasing programs. The "Virginia Jobs and Energy Act" requires lease sale 220 within a year of enactment and mandates at least 2 lease sales in the Virginia lease sale planning area in future 5-year oil and gas leasing programs. NEPA exclusion applies to lease sales conducted under the Act. The "Virginia Jobs and Energy Act" prohibits oil and gas activities off the coast of Virginia that conflict with military operations. The Secretaries of Defense and Interior must periodically review and update the agreement to include new offshore energy technologies. SEC. 4. DISPOSITION OF REVENUE. Payment of Covered Leasing Revenues to States: 37.5 percent of covered leasing revenues from leases in the Virginia lease sale planning area will be allocated to affected States within 200 miles of the leased tract. The allocation of funds to affected States is based on the distances from the coastline to the geographic center of the lease tract. The minimum and maximum allocation percentages vary depending on the State's proximity to the leased tract. Funds allocated to a State under this subsection are available without further appropriation, remain available until expended, and are in addition to any other amounts available under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. States can use the funds for any purpose determined by state laws, except for matching funds for other Federal programs. The term "affected State" is defined as per the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. "Covered leasing revenues" refer to amounts received by the US from leases for energy exploration in the Virginia lease sale planning area. SEC. 5. OFFSHORE METEOROLOGICAL SITE TESTING AND MONITORING PROJECTS. The Secretary of the Interior requires applicants for offshore meteorological projects on the outer Continental Shelf to obtain a permit and right of way within 30 days of application. Public comment and consultation are also part of the process. The Secretary of the Interior mandates that applicants for offshore meteorological projects on the outer Continental Shelf must secure a permit and right of way within 30 days. Public comment and consultation with relevant agencies are required. If the application is denied, clear reasons must be provided to the applicant. The application for offshore meteorological projects on the outer Continental Shelf must be approved within 30 days, with clear reasons for any denials provided to the applicant. The NEPA exclusion does not apply to these projects, and information provided to the Secretary of the Interior is treated as proprietary. An offshore meteorological site testing and monitoring project is defined as a project on or in the waters of the Outer Continental Shelf. Offshore meteorological projects on the Outer Continental Shelf involve testing or monitoring weather using temporary ocean infrastructure, causing minimal disruption to the surface or seafloor. Projects must be decommissioned within 5 years, including removal of infrastructure and site restoration. The project on the Outer Continental Shelf involves testing or monitoring weather using temporary ocean infrastructure. It must be decommissioned within 5 years, including removal of infrastructure and site restoration. Meteorological information obtained by the project is provided to the Secretary of the Interior. The Virginia lease sale planning area is defined as the outer Continental Shelf area with specific boundaries extending from Virginia's seaward boundary to certain latitude and longitude points. SEC. 7. CLARIFICATIONS WITH RESPECT TO EXISTING EXECUTIVE AUTHORITIES. Amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act grants the President the authority to control unleased lands on the outer Continental Shelf.
